Just 3 Object Types to Make Anything
Ideate2D keeps level creation simple and flexible. With just three core object types, you can build just about anythingâ€”from platforms and hazards to interactive environments and effects.

ğŸ”¹ Static Objects
As the name suggests, these objects donâ€™t move on their own and are unaffected by external forces like gravity or collisions.
Use for:


Floors, walls, platforms


Boundaries or barriers


Anything you want to stay put


You can still move static objects (like moving platforms), but only through Special Functionsâ€”custom code you attach to the object.

ğŸ”¸ Dynamic Objects
Dynamic objects respond to external forces. This includes physics, gravity, collisions, and being pushed by the player or other dynamic elements.
Use for:


Players


Enemies


Crates or pushable blocks


Anything that should move naturally in the world



ğŸŒ€ Illusory Objects
These are the most customizable and versatile objects in Ideate2D. Players can see them and walk through them, but canâ€™t interact physically with themâ€”meaning no collisions or physics.
Use for:


Trigger zones (e.g. when a player walks through a hidden checkpoint)


Cosmetic objects like trees, background elements, fog, etc.


Invisible boundaries, event triggers, dialogue popups


With the right Special Function, illusory objects become the backbone of interactivity and immersion.

âœ¨ Custom Objects
Want something truly unique? You can define your own object types!
How:


Open datastructures/objects.py


Create a new class that inherits from object_template


Define custom properties and behaviors



âš™ï¸ Special Functions
Special Functions let you define how an object behaves during the game loop.
Every object in Ideate2D has a Special Function that gets called once per frame. By default, it does nothingâ€”but you can customize it to do anything.
Examples:


A handle_inputs function for the player


A patrol_enemy behavior for a roaming NPC


A trigger_event for an illusory zone


How to create one:


Open datastructures/specials.py


Write a function that takes a single argument (the object itself)


Save the fileâ€”Ideate2Dâ€™s level editor will automatically detect it!


Then just assign your function to any object using the editor.
